Steven Swager }} '''Emerson Drive''' was a Canadian [[country music]] band consisting of Brad Mates (lead vocals), Danick Dupelle (guitars, backing vocals), Mike Melancon (drums), and Dale Wallace (keyboards, backing vocals). The band was founded in 1995 as 12 Gauge, which consisted of Mates, Pat Allingham (fiddle), Steven Swager (bass guitar), Chris Hartman (keyboards), Dan Binns (guitar), David Switzer (guitar), and Remi Barre (drums); Swager was replaced with Jeff Loberg early on. After recording under this name, the band moved to the United States in 1999 and renamed themselves to Emerson Drive. They released two albums for the former [[DreamWorks Records]] Nashville branch: ''[[Emerson Drive (album)|Emerson Drive]]'' in 2002 and ''[[What If? (Emerson Drive album)|What If?]]'' in 2004. These accounted for their first hit singles in the United States: "[[I Should Be Sleeping]]", "[[Fall into Me]]", and "[[Last One Standing (Emerson Drive song)|Last One Standing]]". After DreamWorks closed, Emerson Drive signed with [[Midas Records Nashville]] for the 2006 album ''[[Countrified (Emerson Drive album)|Countrified]]'', which produced their only American number-one single in "[[Moments (Emerson Drive song)|Moments]]". Further releases in the United States were unsuccessful, but the band continued to chart in Canada through releases on [[Open Road Recordings]] and Big Star Recordings over the next ten years. ==History== ===12 Gauge, ''Until You Walk the Tracks'' – 1995–1998=== Emerson Drive was formed under the name of 12 Gauge in February 1995 when Brad Mates entered a talent contest at his local high school in [[Grande Prairie]], [[Alberta]]. Through the contest, Mates met fiddler Pat Allingham, bass player Steven Swager and keyboardist Chris Hartman. Mates, Hartman, Swager and Allingham decided to form a band with guitarists Dan Binns and David Switzer, bass guitarist Jeff Loberg, and drummer Remi Barre. The band started practicing in Mates' basement and entering contests. In 1996, the group entered a local Battle of the Bands contest and won the opportunity to write and record their EP ''Open Season''. In 1996, 12 Gauge began work on their first studio album and independently released, ''Until You Walk the Tracks'' in 1997. Through 1997 and 1998, the group toured Canada to support their album and charted two songs, including the top 40 single, "Some Trains Never Come", which peaked at No. 36 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks chart in 1998.{{cite web |title=RPM Country 100 |url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/item.aspx?IdNumber=2293& |website=bac-lac.gc.ca | date=17 July 2013 |publisher=Library and Archives Canada |access-date=2021-10-15}} Both singles were accompanied by music videos that received airplay on [[CMT (Canada)|CMT Canada]]. In early 1998, the group received a nomination for Top New Group or Duo at the RPM Big Country Awards, but lost to [[Montana Sky (band)|Montana Sky]]. By this time, Switzer had left the group and drummer Remi Barre had been replaced by Derrick Kuzemchuk. Soon after the release, Binns left the group. He was replaced by Dan Bauman, who stayed with the band for just over a year. By the end of 1998, Binns and Kuzemchuk left the group. Shortly after, the band hired Gerry Leiske as their manager, replacing previous manager Lionel Allingham (Pat's father). Leiske introduced the band to guitarist Danick Dupelle, who had been performing with Canadian country trio [[Farmer's Daughter (band)|Farmer's Daughter]], which Leiske also managed. Drummer Mike Melancon replaced Kuzemchuk. ===Name Change, Nashville & ''Emerson Drive'' – 1999–2002=== In 1999, the band moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in search of a record deal. In the process, they discovered that '12 Gauge' was also the name of an American rapper and had to choose a new name; Emerson Drive is named for the Emerson Trail that crosses Western Alberta and joins the [[Alaska Highway]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mg8EAAAAMBAJ&q=emerson+drive&pg=PA52|title=Constant Touring Does the Trick for DreamWork's Emerson Drive|access-date=2009-12-31|publisher=[[Billboard Magazine]]|date=2002-05-18}} The group caught the attention of executives at [[DreamWorks Records]] subsidiary DreamWorks Nashville, who signed the group to a record deal in 2000. Emerson Drive's debut album, ''[[Emerson Drive (album)|Emerson Drive]]'', was scheduled to be released in January 2002, but was delayed when DreamWorks executives found two new songs and brought in singer-songwriter [[Richard Marx]] to produce.{{cite web |title=Richard Marx Produces Emerson Drive, Aug 2003 |url=https://www.mixonline.com/recording/richard-marx-produces-emerson-drive-373254 |website=mixonline.com |date=8 August 2003 |publisher=MIX |access-date=2021-10-15}} The album was released in May 2002; it ranked No. 67 on the Billboard Top Country Album charts for 2003.{{cite web |title=Top Country Albums 2003 |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2003/top-country-albums |website=billboard.com |publisher=Billboard |access-date=2021-10-15}} Emerson Drive's debut American single, "[[I Should Be Sleeping]]", was released in November 2001. The song became a hit for the group on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Single & Tracks]] chart in 2002, peaking at No. 4 and finishing the year at No. 22.{{cite web |title=Hot Country Songs 2002 |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2002/hot-country-songs |website=billboard.com |publisher=Billboard |access-date=2021-10-15}} The album's second single, "Fall into Me", one of the two new songs Marx produced, was issued in late 2002. It peaked at No. 3 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart in 2003, settling at No. 36 at year end.{{cite web |title=2003 in country music |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_in_country_music |website=en.wikipedia.org |publisher=Wikipedia |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{Circular reference|date=April 2022}}{{cite web |title=Hot Country Songs 2003 |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2003/hot-country-songs |website=billboard.com |publisher=Billboard |access-date=2021-10-15}} In Canada, it charted at No. 35 in 2002 and No. 32 in 2003, while "I Should Be Sleeping" charted at No. 40.{{citation needed|date=May 2024}} Reviews of ''Emerson Drive'' were favorable,{{cite web |last1=Doerschuk |first1=Robert L. |title=Emerson Drive Review |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/emerson-drive-mw0000215482 |website=allmusic.com |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{cite web |title=Customer Reviews, Emerson Drive |url=https://www.amazon.ca/Emerson-Drive/dp/B000066EZ5 |website=amazon.ca |publisher=Amazon |access-date=2021-10-15}} and the band toured in support of it, playing several solo concerts and festivals, and opening for [[Keith Urban]], [[Brad Paisley]] and [[Brooks and Dunn]].{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive Tour & Concert History |url=https://www.concertarchives.org/bands/emerson-drive?page=3#concert-table |website=concertarchives.org |publisher=Concert Archives |access-date=2021-10-15}} In 2002, the [[Academy of Country Music]] named Emerson Drive Top New Vocal Duo or Group,{{cite web |title=Top New Vocal Duo or Group 2002 |url=https://www.acmcountry.com/winners?awardTitle=Emerson+Drive&awardCategory=&awardYear=&actionButton=Submit |website=acmcountry.com |publisher=Academy of Country Music |access-date=2021-10-15}} and the band won Top New Artist at the [[Radio & Records]] Year-End Awards. At the [[Canadian Country Music Association]] awards, the band won Group or Duo of the Year and the Chevy Trucks Rising Star Award. Beginning in August 2002, the band went through member changes with the departure of bassist Jeff Loberg, who exited the group to focus on his songwriting. Loberg was replaced by Patrick Bourque. In 2003, keyboardist Chris Hartman left to return to school, and was replaced by Dale Wallace; Pat Allingham left to spend more time with his family and was replaced by David Pichette. ===''What If?'' – 2004–2005=== Emerson Drive released its second album, ''[[What If? (Emerson Drive album)|What If?]]''{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive – What If? |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/3933633-Emerson-Drive-What-If |website=discogs.com |publisher=Discogs |access-date=2021-10-15}} on July 10, 2004. The album, which was also produced by Richard Marx, debuted at No. 12 on the ''Billboard'' Top Country Albums chart.{{cite web |title=2004 in country music |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_in_country_music |website=en.wikipedia.org |publisher=Wikipedia |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{Circular reference|date=April 2022}} The album's first single, "Waitin' on Me", was released to Canada only in late 2003; the next single, "Last One Standing", was released in Canada and the US in January 2004. Reviews of ''What If?'' were mixed{{cite web |last1=MacIntosh |first1=Dan |title=What If? Emerson Drive |url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=714 |website=countrystandardtime.com |publisher=Country Standard Time |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{cite web |title=Customer Review What If? |url=https://www.amazon.com/What-If-Emerson-Drive-2004-06-29/product-reviews/B00Y3ZMZ9M |website=amazom.com |publisher=Amazon |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive Album: "What If?" |url=http://www.bestcountrysingers.com/emerson-drive/albums/pre-ipC516220.html |website=bestcountrysingers.com |publisher=Best Country Singers |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{cite web |last1=Erlewine |first1=Stephen Thomas |title=What If? Review |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/what-if-mw0000697119 |website=allmusic.com |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2021-10-15}} but the band was signed as the opener for [[Shania Twain]]'s [[Up! Tour]]. The tour began on September 25, 2003, and ended in July 2004. During this time, the band performed twice at the Grand Ole Opry.{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive's Concert History |url=https://www.concertarchives.org/bands/emerson-drive?page=2 |website=concertarchives.org |publisher=Concert Archives |access-date=2021-10-15}} In 2004, DreamWorks Nashville was sold to [[Universal Music Group]], which released two more singles from ''What If?'' in Canada, through Universal Music Canada in 2005. Universal shut down DreamWorks Nashville and Emerson Drive was dropped. ===''Countrified'' – 2005–2006=== In late 2005, [[Keith Follesé]] and Brad Allen signed the band to their new label, [[Midas Records Nashville]] and the band began working on Emerson Drive's third album; [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]]'s Teddy Gentry and veteran Nashville musician and songwriter [[Josh Leo]] were brought in to produce. ''[[Countrified (Emerson Drive album)|Countrified]]'' was released in September 2006, debuting at No. 30 on the ''Billboard'' Top Country Songs chart. The album's first single, "[[A Good Man (song)|A Good Man]]," reached No. 17 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart (No. 5 in Canada) and was followed by "[[Moments (Emerson Drive song)|Moments]]", which gave the group their first (and only) No. 1 single (No 4 in Canada). Emerson Drive became the first Canadian group to reach number one and the fifth Canadian act overall. "Moments" was followed in Canada by the top-five hit "Testify" and in the United States by the top-25 hit "[[You Still Own Me]]", a cover the 2004 [[Johnny Reid]] single.{{cite web |title=2006 in country music |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_in_country_music |website=en.wikipedia.org |publisher=Wikipedia |access-date=2021-10-16}}{{Circular reference|date=April 2022}}{{cite web |title=2007 in country music |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_in_country_music |website=wikipedia.org |publisher=Wikipedia |access-date=2021-10-16}}{{Circular reference|date=April 2022}} ''Countrified'' won rave reviews.{{cite web |title=Countrified |url=https://www.amazon.ca/Countrified-Emerson-Drive/dp/B000H5VF4S |website=amazon.ca |publisher=Amazon |access-date=2021-10-16}}{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive Album: "Countrified" |url=http://www.bestcountrysingers.com/emerson-drive/albums/pre-id34720367.html |website=bestcountrysingers.com |publisher=Best Country Singers |access-date=2021-10-16}}{{cite web |last1=Widran |first1=Jonathan |title=Countrified Review |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/countrified-mw0000425012 |website=allmusic.com |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2021-10-16}} At the [[Juno Awards of 2007]], ''Countrified'' was nominated for Country Recording of the Year{{cite web |title=Past Nominees & Winners |url=https://junoawards.ca/awards/past-winners-nominees/?search_year_val1=1970&search_year_val2=2021&search_category_val=&search_wins_val=no&tag_search_val=emerson+drive&submit=submit |website=junoawards.ca |publisher=Juno Awards |access-date=2021-10-16}} and at the [[42nd Academy of Country Music Awards]], the band was nominated Top Vocal Group of the Year. The video for "Moments"{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive - moments |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HQ3-PHktE34 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211222/HQ3-PHktE34 |archive-date=2021-12-22 |url-status=live|website=youtube.com |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2021-10-16}}{{cbignore}} won CMT Video of the Year, and at the Canadian Country Music Awards, the song won Single of the Year, and the band won Group or Duo of the Year. "Moments" was nominated as Best Country Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals at the [[49th Annual Grammy Awards]]. ===''Believe'' – 2007–2010=== Bassist Patrick Bourque resigned from the band in August 2007 and, the following month, took his own life, at age 30. The members of Emerson Drive learned of his death while traveling to a concert in [[Valentine, Nebraska]]. In November, the band talked with [[CBC News]] saying they had known that Bourque had been unhappy, but "nobody could do anything for him".{{cite web |agency=The Canadian Press |title=Emerson Drive remembers Patrick Bourque, Nov 2007 |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/emerson-drive-remembers-patrick-bourque-1.655259 |website=cbc.ca |publisher=CBC News |access-date=2021-10-15}} Emerson Drive toured the US in support of ''Believe'' through 2007, playing solo concerts and several festivals, including the 2007 [[CMA Music Festival]]. In October of that year, they accompanied [[Porter Wagoner]], [[Trent Tomlinson]], [[The Whites]], [[Ricky Skaggs]] and [[Carrie Underwood]] in concert at the [[Grand Ole Opry]].{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive's Concert & Tour History |url=https://www.concertarchives.org/bands/emerson-drive?page=1#concert-table |website=concertarchives.org |publisher=Concert Archives |access-date=2021-10-15}} Producer and [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]] bassist Teddy Gentry was quoted as calling Emerson Drive “possibly the best band I’ve heard in years, as far as playing live on stage.”.{{cite web |last1=Kershner |first1=Jim |title=Emerson Drive's road hardly easy, July 2009 |url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/jul/10/emerson-drives-road-hardly-easy/ |website=spokesman.com |publisher=The Spokesman-Review |access-date=2021-10-15}} The band began recording their sixth album in 2008, with session bassists [[Michael Rhodes (musician)|Michael Rhodes]] and [[Glenn Worf]], and [[Arlo Gilliam]] as touring bassist.{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive, Believe, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/believe-mw0000813067/credits |website=allmusic.com |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2021-10-15}} In November 2008, they released their first new single, "[[Belongs to You]]",{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive - Belongs To You |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=it5I4ezDY0c |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211222/it5I4ezDY0c |archive-date=2021-12-22 |url-status=live|website=youtube.com |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{cbignore}} on Midas and new label [[Valory Music Group]], which began to promote the band in mid-2008. The song peaked at No. 32 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart in March 2009,{{cite web |title=Billboard March 2009 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Huu90EQHpEC&q=Billboard+March+2009+emerson+drive&pg=PT48 |date = 7 March 2009|publisher=Billboard |access-date=2021-10-15}} and the new album, ''[[Believe (Emerson Drive album)|Believe]]'' was released in May 2009, in Canada only.{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive – Believe |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/10036207-Emerson-Drive-Believe |website=discogs.com |publisher=Discogs |access-date=2021-10-15}} In November 2008, Valory (now [[Big Machine Records]]) entered into partnership with Midas and the band signed with [[Open Road Recordings]]. As the band was embroiled in a dispute with Midas, this left them without a USA-based label and ''Believe'' was not released in the United States at the time.{{cite web |last1=Bjorke |first1=Matt |title=Emerson Drive - A Decade of Drive, Feb 2011 |url=https://roughstock.com/news/2011/02/18643-emerson-drive-a-decade-of-drive |website=roughstock.com |publisher=Roughstock |access-date=2021-10-15}} Despite this, the group achieved three more top ten hits in Canada with "Believe," "I Love This Road," and "The Extra Mile". [[File:Emerson Drive at CMA Music Festival (c. 2010).jpg|thumb|Emerson Drive at the [[CMA Music Festival]]]] In 2010, the band founded its own label, Amdian Records.{{cite web |url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/07/29/emerson-drive-record-label/|title=Emerson Drive Start Their Own Record Label|access-date=2010-07-29|publisher=The Boot}} The first single, "That Kind of Beautiful", was released in Canada in June 2010 and in the United States in August. ''Believe'' was very well received.{{cite web |last1=Bjorke |first1=Matt |title=Emerson Drive - Believe, June 2009 |url=https://roughstock.com/news/2009/06/20774-emerson-drive-believe |website=roughstock.com |publisher=Roughstock |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{cite web |last1=Sterling |first1=Todd |title=Believe Review |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/believe-mw0000813067 |website=allmusic.com |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2021-10-15}}{{cite web |title=Amazon Customer Reviews |url=https://www.amazon.ca/Believe-Emerson-Drive/dp/B0024FE7I0 |website=amazon.com |publisher=Amazon |access-date=2021-10-15}} In 2009, Emerson Drive was nominated as by the [[Canadian Country Music Association]] Awards as Group of the Year.{{cite web |title=2009 Canadian Country Music Association Awards Nominees Announced, July 2009 |url=https://aristopr.com/2009-canadian-country-music-association-awards-nominees-announced/ |website=aristopr.com |publisher=Aristo PR |website=junoawards.ca |publisher=Juno Awards |access-date=2021-10-15}} ===''Decade of Drive'' – 2011=== Open Road Recordings released the band's greatest hits album, ''[[Decade of Drive]]'', on February 8, 2011, in Canada.{{cite web |last1=Leggett |first1=Steve |title=Decade of Drive: 10 Years of Hits Review |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/decade-of-drive-10-years-of-hits-mw0002096013 |website=allmusic.com |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2021-10-16}} The album featured the band's biggest hits and new previously unreleased songs.{{cite web |url=http://emersondrive.com/?news_id=19104&inc=5|title=Country Stars Emerson Drive Announce 33-City Canadian Tour And Hits Package|access-date=2010-11-29|publisher=Emerson Drive official website}} Its first single, "When I See You Again", which was written as a tribute to Patrick Bourque, was released in November 2010 and peaked at No. 97. The second single, "Let Your Love Speak", peaked at No. 89. The third single, "Sleep It Off", did not chart. In January 2011, Emerson Drive signed with Quarterback Records to release "Let Your Love Speak" to U.S. radio.{{cite web |url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/86637/emerson-drive-announces-partnership-with-quarterba|title=Emerson Drive Announces Partnership With Quarterback Records|access-date=2011-02-01|publisher=All Access}} The band began its Canadian ''Decade and Driving Tour'' on February 8, 2011.{{cite web |last1=Wilger |first1=Devin |title=Emerson Drive celebrates 10 years of hits in Yorkton |url=https://www.sasktoday.ca/yorkton-news-review-archive/emerson-drive-celebrates-10-years-of-hits-in-yorkton-4065239 |website=sasktoday.ca |publisher=Yorkton News Review |access-date=2021-10-16}} ===''Roll'' and ''Tilt-a-Whirl'' – 2012–2015=== Emerson Drive's seventh studio album, ''[[Roll (Emerson Drive album)|Roll]]'', was released on October 30, 2012.{{cite news|last=Betts|first=Stephen L.|title=Emerson Drive Has New Music Ready to 'Roll'|url=http://www.theboot.com/2012/10/01/emerson-drive-album-roll/|access-date=October 1, 2012|newspaper=The Boot|date=October 1, 2012}} The album's first single, "[[She's My Kind of Crazy]]", was released to Canadian country radio on July 9, 2012. The second single, "[[Let It Roll (Emerson Drive song)|Let It Roll]]" (with [[Doc Walker]]) was released to Canadian country radio on October 23, 2012. The third single, "With You" was released to Canadian country radio in March 2013. The fourth, "She Always Get What She Wants" was released to Canadian country radio in June 2013.{{cite web |last1=Bjorke |first1=Matt |title=Album Review: Emerson Drive - Roll, Feb 2013 |url=https://roughstock.com/news/2013/02/16041-album-review-emerson-drive-roll |website=roughstock.com |publisher=Roughstock |access-date=2021-10-17}} The band then criss-crossed Canada as part of the CMT Hitlist Tour 2013.{{cite web |title=CMT Hitlist Tour 2013 |url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLk1WBMwpIXky_0DoCq96VYmibvM1pJwtL |website=youtube.com |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2021-10-17}} In May 2013, fiddle-player David Pichette left the band to focus on his family.{{cite web |last1=Conaway |first1=Alanna |title=David Pichette Leaves Emerson Drive, May 2013 |url=https://roughstock.com/news/2013/05/15315-roughstock-exclusive-david-pichette-leaves-emerson-drive |website=roughstock.com |publisher=Roughstock |access-date=2021-10-17}} He was not replaced. Emerson Drive's first EP album, ''Tilt-a-Whirl'', was released on April 14, 2015, on Universal Music Canada.{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive – Tilt-A-Whirl |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/10036255-Emerson-Drive-Tilt-A-Whirl |website=discogs.com |publisher=Discogs |access-date=2021-10-17}} Three singles, "Who We Are", "Till the Summer's Gone," and "Good Hurt," were released to Canadian country radio in 2015. ===Farewell — 2017–2024=== Emerson Drive released the single, "Just Got Paid" to Canadian country radio on 2017. The song peaked at number 10 on the ''Billboard'' Canada Country chart. In 2019, the band released the single “Country People”.{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive Has This Week's Hot New Radio Single, April 2019 |url=https://www.fyimusicnews.ca/articles/2019/04/14/emerson-drive-has-weeks-hot-new-radio-single |website=fyimusicnews.ca |publisher=FYI Music News |access-date=2021-10-17}} In August 2021, the band posted on its Facebook page that it was recording new music.{{cite web |title=Emerson Drive |url=https://www.facebook.com/emersondrive |website=facebook.com |publisher=Facebook |access-date=2021-10-17}} In 2023, Emerson Drive independently released the single "Break Us", while announcing they would embark on their final tour in 2024.{{cite web|url=https://frontporchmusic.ca/emerson-drive-final-song-break-us-and-tour/|title=The End Of An Era: Emerson Drive Announces Final Tour and New Single "Break Us"|date=November 16, 2023|work=Front Porch Music|first=Jenna|last=Weishar|access-date=November 27, 2023}} ==Personnel== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Current members * Brad Mates – lead vocals (1995–present) * Danick Dupelle – guitars, backing vocals (1998–present) * Mike Melancon – drums (1998–present) * Dale Wallace – keyboards, vocals (2003–present) {{col-2}} ;Former members * Pat Allingham – fiddle (1995–2003) * Chris Hartman – keyboards (1995–2003) * Jeff Loberg – bass (1995–2002) * Dan Binns – guitars (1995–1998) * David Switzer – guitars (1995–1998) * Remi Barre – drums (1995–1998) * Derrick Kuzemchuk – drums (1998) * Dan Bauman – guitars (1998) * Patrick Bourque – bass (2002–2007; died 2007) * David Pichette – fiddle (2003–2013) {{col-end}} ;Lineups {| class="toccolours" border=1 cellpadding=2 cellspacing=0 style="float: width: 375px; margin: 0 0 1em 1em; border-collapse: collapse; border: 1px solid #E2E2E2;" width=99% |- !
